abstract.p: The brain of a 5-year-old boy with Schinzel-Giedion syndrome displayed a cobblestone appearance of orbital and lateral aspects of frontal lobes due to widespread glioneuronal meningeal heterotopia. Meningeal heterotopia consisted of scattered neurons, neurofilament positive axons, and myelinated fibers accompanied by striking astrocytic gliosis. The underlying cortex showed gaps in the pial basal lamina, distorted neuronal layering, and focal polymicrogyria. The number of capillaries appeared increased throughout the brain. Mild hydrocephalus was associated with a slight atrophy of corpus callosum as well as villous hyperplasia and marked stromal degeneration of the choroid plexus. Our findings suggest that Schinzel-Giedion syndrome may represent One more entity within enlarging spectrum of lissencephalic cortical dysplasia syndromes.

body.p: Schinzel-Giedion syndrome is a rare pediatric disease entity characterized by a variable-combination severe developmental delay, facial dysmorphic features, hypertrichosis, multiple skeletal abnormalities, renal and cardiac malformations, frequent association with neuroectodermal tumors as well as hydrocephalus, brain atrophy, and occasional cases of agenesis or atrophy of the corpus callosum.1–13 Majority of children die before the age of 2 years.13 Scanty neuropathologic studies are limited to a single case of a newborn girl with this disease.2 Here we report neuropathologic findings in a 5-year-old microcephalic boy with Schinzel-Giedion syndrome and clinically suspected hypoplasia of corpus callosum.

sec.title: Clinical History
sec.p: This 5-year-old boy had a lifelong history of seizure disorder, gastroesophageal reflux, umbilical and bilateral inguinal hernia, bilateral vesicoureteral reflux, hydronephrosis, hypospadias, and severe global developmental delay. Cytogenetic testing revealed 46,XY male karyotype and normal microarrays. Family history was noncontributory.

Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) performed at the age of 4.5 years showed thin and underdeveloped corpus callosum, slight atrophy of brain and brainstem, normal cerebellum, and ex vacuo dilation of the lateral and third ventricles. The Sylvian fissures were prominent and extra-axial cerebral spinal fluid spaces in the middle cranial fossa were enlarged. The cerebral cortex displayed smooth gyration and shallow sulci suggestive of pachygyria associated with subtle bilateral occipital polymicrogyria. The right lateral ventricle contained a 2.2 × 1.9 × 1.9-cm mass appearing as either choroid plexus or ependymal cyst.
His last admission to the hospital for H1N1 infection was complicated by aspiration pneumonia, progressing to severe respiratory distress and death.

Autopsy revealed a male child appearing smaller for his age with crown-to-heel length of 81.0 cm (expected 102-116 cm) and abundant hairy skin mainly at the dorsal aspect of the trunk, shoulders, dorsolateral aspect of 4 extremities, and both cheeks. His head circumference measured 45 cm (healthy range, 48.5-54 cm). He was blond-haired with low posterior and anterior hairline, long midface, low-set ears with enlarged rounded ear lobules, prominent folding of the helix and antihelixes, and deep exaggerated concha and fossa of both ears. His nose was small with anteverted nares. The mouth was enlarged with long philtrum measuring 1.5 cm. The neck was short. The chest increased in anteroposterior dimension because of mild to moderate kyphosis at the lower thoracic region. The vertebral column had mild right convex scoliosis at the thoracic region. The nipples were hypoplastic. The external genitalia had ambiguous appearance, with abundant foreskin and scrotal skin mimicking vulvar labia and showing features of hypospadias. The left testicle was undescended. All extremities were symmetrically contracted with mild antecubital and popliteal flexure. Hands showed bilateral syndactyly between the fourth and fifth fingers, and mild nail clubbing of both thumbs. Palmar creases appeared normal. The right foot had the third toe with plantar flexion and overlapped by the second and fourth toe. There were no abnormal plantar creases. Autopsy revealed bilateral confluent bronchopneumonia as well as hydronephrosis and multiple cysts in both kidneys.

The brain was examined after 2 weeks of fixation in formalin. The brain weighed 747 g (healthy range, 1237-1300 g), the brainstem and cerebellum 74 g, and the cerebellum alone 63 g (expected, 65 g for the above total weight of the brain).14 The frontal lobes displayed broad gyri covered by whitish and thickened meninges, especially over the convexities and along the Sylvian fissure. The gyri of the lateral and orbital surfaces of both frontal lobes were markedly broadened and displayed either smooth or cobblestone-like surfaces (Figure 1). The olfactory nerves were normal. The occipital lobe showed excessive gyral folding with very deep sulci on the lateral surface of both hemispheres. Coronal sections of the cerebral hemispheres revealed broad flattened gyri of the lateral and inferior aspects of frontal lobes, with serrated gray-white matter junction (Figure 2). The moderately enlarged ventricular system contained expanded glomus of the choroid plexus, almost entirely filling the posterior compartment of the right lateral ventricle (not shown). The choroid plexus of the left lateral horn was also prominent with a similar microcystic gelatinous nodule measuring approximately 2.5 × 2 to 3 × 3.0 cm at the largest diameter. The corpus callosum was slightly thinner than normal and the crura of fornix were slightly atrophic. The mammillary bodies were unremarkable. Vessels of the circle of Willis were normal. The pons was flattened. Medulla oblongata and cerebellum were normal. Only the cervical level of the spinal cord was available for examination and it was unremarkable.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Standard neuropathologic set of sections from all brain areas as well as grossly described abnormalities were sampled for microscopic examination. The sections were processed to paraffin embedding and stained with hematoxylin and eosin, and in Luxol fast blue with PAS methods. Selected sections were routinely immunostained for the following tissue antigens with commercially available primary antibodies (all from Dako, Carpenteria, California): glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP, polyclonal, 1:3000 dilution), myelin basic protein (polyclonal 1:50 dilution), neurofilament (monoclonal 1:4000, clone 2F11), synaptophysin (monoclonal 1:25, clone SY38), chromogranin (monoclonal DAK-A3, 1:100), and epithelial membrane antigen (clone E29 1:100). In addition, antibodies against merosin (laminin alpha-2 chain, 1:1000, clone 5H2; Chemicon, Temacula, California), calretinin (polyclonal 1:200; Invitrogen, Camarillo, California), and CD34 (clone QBEND, 1:50; Novocastra, Newcastle-upon-Tyne) were also applied. Streptavidin/biotin detection system (Histostatin Plus; Invitrogen) was used for visualization of the immune reactions and followed by light hematoxylin counterstain. Immunohistochemistry was performed using LabVision autostainer. Retrieval with Citrate at pH 6.0 was necessary for localization of synaptophysin, calretinin, and chromogranin.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Microscopic examination of multiple sections from both frontal lobes revealed widespread glioneuronal bridges extending from the cortex to the overlying leptomeninges through wide gaps in the pial basal lamina and glia limitans (Figure 3). Meningeal heterotopia appeared as a discontinuous, up to 5-mm-thick, neuropil-like tissue with scattered small neurons and haphazard strands of myelinated neurofilament-positive axons, on the background of gliosis with hypertrophic astrocytes (Figure 4). All the detectable heterotopic neurons and the surrounding background displayed strong immunoreactivity for calretinin, strikingly similar in intensity to the adjacent upper cortical layers. This immunostaining also accentuated apparent polymicrogyria in the grossly broadened gyri in the frontal cortex (Figure 5). Synaptophysin in the heterotopic nests was much weaker than in the adjacent cortex. The underlying cerebral cortex showed loss of normal lamination and radial bundles of myelinated axons and capillaries extending into meninges. Heterotopic tissue in the depth of sulci occasionally bridged the facing cortical surfaces. The occipital cortex was histologically normal whereas temporal and parietal lobes showed minimal architectural abnormalities with only a few minute meningeal heterotopia around the basal aspect of the inferior temporal and parahippocampal gyri. The neuronal population appeared slightly depleted in all the cortical regions, most evidently in the dentate gyrus. Multiple small heterotopic foci of brain tissue were also found in the meninges around the pons, medulla oblongata, and in the anterior fissure of the cervical spinal cord. Numerous telangiectatic capillaries were observed throughout the brain, including corpus callosum and choroid plexus. Leptomeninges were generally thickened and fibrotic, especially over the convexities of the frontal lobes.

Low-power view from the area of polymicrogyria in the frontal cortex (illustrated in Figure 2) immunostained for calretinin. Remarkable similarity of intensity of immunostain in the upper layers of the cortex and heterotopic tissue. sec.p: The basal ganglia, thalami, and midbrain showed no abnormalities. The pons was flattened because of atrophy or hypoplasia of corticospinal tracts that also extended to the medulla oblongata and cervical spinal cord. The cerebellar white matter contained small focus of heterotopic dentate nucleus neurons.

The grossly expanded choroid plexus displayed pronounced myxoid and cystic degeneration of the stroma, and slight villous hyperplasia. There was no sign of nuclear atypia or mitotic activity in the epithelium. The posterior horn of the left lateral ventricle showed widespread loss of ependyma and subependymal implantations of choroid plexus epithelium, often deeply embedded into gliotic ventricular wall.
Striated muscle was normal. Laminin immunoreactivity in the meninges and muscle was similar to control tissues.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The diagnosis of Schinzel-Giedion syndrome in this patient is based on characteristic manifestations of multisystem disease with genital and skeletal abnormalities, facial dysmorphism, hirsutism, hydronephrosis with renal cysts, and severe developmental delay.1–13 This multiorgan involvement could be explained by a recent discovery of sporadic, heterogeneous de novo mutation involving ubiquitous SET-binding protein (SETBP1), that is present in all normal tissues.15 Although more than 30 years passed since the first clinical description of Schinzel-Giedion syndrome, very limited information is available on the pathologic basis of this syndrome. Few neuropathologic and/or radiologic observations demonstrated inconsistent spectrum of abnormalities, such as unilateral absence of gyrus rectus and the olfactory nerve with otherwise preserved gyral pattern,2 shortened frontal operculum,4 thin or absent corpus callosum,2,4,6,7 absence of cranial nerves with normal cranial nerve nuclei,2 aqueductal forking associated with relatively mild or moderate hydrocephalus, and multiple subependymal “cysts” with gliosis as well as perivascular and parenchymal calcifications in the basal ganglia.2 Cerebral atrophy with relative preservation of brainstem and cerebellum is seen radiologically in the majority of patients. Agenesis of corpus callosum, hydrocephalus, and wide Sylvian fissure were also mentioned in 1 postmortem study and callosal atrophy in another, without microscopic details.3,7 One of the patients reported by Schinzel and Giedion had “abnormal gyration of the cerebral cortex and subdural and subarachnoid hemorrhage,” with no microscopic documentation of the nature or localization of the abnormalities.1 In rare cases, the brain was described as normal on radiologic and postmortem studies.5

The patient reported here displays obvious developmental abnormalities concentrated in the anterior components of pallium. “Cobblestone” cortical malformation is recognized as a consequence of overmigration of the immature neuronal and glial cells above the pial layer, because of widespread breaks in the pial basal lamina.16–18 It has been demonstrated that normal architecture of the cerebral cortex depends on the establishment of marginal zone with intact pial glia limitans that provides a barrier restricting further outward migration of neurons.17,18 Interestingly, in our case, all the heterotopic neurons and their “neuropil” displayed calretinin immunoreactivity similar to that in the underlying superficial layers of the cerebral cortex. In the normal brains, calretinin is expressed in the cortical interneurons that migrate tangentially from ganglionic eminence of the ventral forebrain.19 Defect in this pattern of migration has been suggested in some genetic forms of human lissencephalies20 and may have contributed to the development of heterotopia in our patient. Aberrant neuronal migration resulting in cobblestone features with greatest involvement of the anterior part of the brain has been observed in autosomal recessive frontoparietal polymicrogyria20 and in the most severe cases of type II lissencephaly.16 This anomaly is shared by several closely related forms of cerebro-ocular dysplasia, namely, Walker-Warburg syndrome, Fukuyama congenital muscular dystrophy, and some cases of muscle-eye-brain syndrome.16 Unlike Fukuyama type of dystrophy, leptomeningeal heterotopia in our patient was not associated with any evidence of muscle disease. Absence of eye pathology and essentially normal cerebellum distinguishes this syndrome from other forms of cerebro-ocular dysplasia or classical lissencephaly type II.16 However, occasional cases of isolated cobblestone lissencephaly without muscle or eye pathology has been reported previously,21 and the spectrum of these developmental diseases is likely to expand.

The choroid plexus “cysts” have been previously observed radiologically in three Schinzel-Giedion syndrome cases.3,9 Suspected cyst in our patient was in fact stromal degeneration associated with focal villous hyperplasia of choroid plexus. Despite radiologic suspicion of corpus callosum agenesis or hypoplasia in this as well as previously reported cases of Schinzel-Giedion syndrome,2–4,6,7,10 the corpus callosum was only slightly reduced in size. Thinning of the corpus callosum in our patient was most likely a component of generalized brain atrophy with the contributing detrimental effect of choroid plexus hyperplasia and hydrocephalus.

Very scanty, inconsistent, and often incomplete neuropathologic findings in Schinzel-Giedion syndrome do not allow at this point for definition of this syndrome as a clear-cut clinicopathologic entity. However, one of the patients in the original publication by Schinzel and Giedion showed radiologic brain abnormalities suggestive of broad gyri, possibly cobblestone lissencephaly. Additional reports on this rare condition are needed to learn whether cobblestone cortical changes represent one of the essential elements of diagnostic brain abnormalities in Schinzel-Giedion syndrome.
